pros: Colleagues are often other students so you make diverse friends on the job, flexible hours, decent pay. Contract locations are generally on campus or nearby. I enjoyed doing the jobs to promote the university during Open days on campus or externally in schools. It was really convenient to work on campus. As a commuting student, I found this great as I'd often have just one or two lectures in the day. So I spent the rest of the time on jobs.
cons: - Sometimes there won't be a university staff to look over the work or supervise you /the team. In this case, some students haughtily act like they were the designated as supervisor or try to assign you work. - You'll be on your feet mostly but that's expected.

review_title: Staff lovely, management could use some work

pros:
I only worked on site for a couple of months before the lockdown and the campus was lovely. Plenty of places to eat or go for drinks after work. The people I worked with were great.

The salary was good, it was a lot more than a previous job where I'd have a great deal more responsibility, autonomy and more to do.
cons:
Not sure if my poor experience was due to the pandemic or not, but they handled the pandemic really poorly. There was an insane amount of pressure to keep the numbers up and no acknowledgement of the external factors that were making that next to impossible. 

Management was very pressuring, negative and thoughtless. Very little thought seemed to be given to the mental and physical health of the team.

The job itself was so bureaucratic that it heavily constrained what you could do in the job, making it both boring for me and frustrating for the academics you work with. 

They restructure quite often, so they seem to be aware of the problems, but they just fall back into old patterns. It was a very draining experience.

pros: Very supportive place to work and good progression opportunities

There was extensive training so I was confident in the role and also training in interpersonal skills which was beneficial to future jobs since graduating.
cons: There is a 6 hour maximum a week, so this job cannot pay for much, it was also sometimes difficult to get 6 hours of work a week if you were not needed. Some of the 'paperwork' type activities which went alongside felt as though I was ticking boxes and weren't personalised to my work on the course.

review_title: Narrow agenda and discrimination between different academic staff
pros: Students are interesting and exciting to work with. Generally supportive colleagues. Paid-for PG Cert in Higher Education (but that is standard in all universities now). Comparatively good quality facilities and IT support.
cons: Aloof Head of Department, not interested in speaking to or supporting staff, especially temporary staff. Fixed-term staff on 6-month contracts loaded with far more teaching than permanent staff. Staff told contract would end, or that core modules are not running via email, no discussion. Staff effort, contribution and creativity not recognised: focus only on negatives and on meeting narrow agenda.  No support for research, and requests for conference support can be rejected abruptly without a good justification. Management undermines old staff and their research, giving promotions to new people--some of them underqualified--whose research subject matches the management agenda. No adacemic quality or achievement criteria. Staff are unhappy and are constantly leaving. HR department also abrupt, and not particularly interested in staff feedback. Admin does parties, cards and gifts only for permanent contract staff and never for fixed terms, even if they have longer service.

job_title: Graduate Academic Assistant in Hendon, England
pros:
Middlesex University is a great place to work due to the amount of diversity and the people you get to meet from all over the world, including the students and staff.

Most of the academic staff you get to work with have extensive industry experience, they are always very supportive and encouraging whether it comes to working with them as colleagues or getting advice on your studies, they are always there to listen.

One of the amazing perks of working at Middlesex University is that, along with the job you may get the chance to study for a qualification funded by the university, however, this depends on your manager.
cons: No set career path, more training and a supportive approach to keep staff in the company would be really good for staff who are loyal to the organisation.

pros: Good colleagues and the opportunity to work with people from different disciplines and backgrounds.
cons: As an emerging institution it is overly not as sophisticated as more established institutions where academics of all disciplines contribute to teaching, research and service.  Mdx has developed a policy (in order to bolster REF ratings) where new appointments are made that are teaching and service light making it difficult for emerging academics to develop research in a supportive environment as they carry heavy teaching and administrative loads in order to allow for these REF research positions.

review_title: A shambolic organisation to the highest degree!
pros: - The annual leave allowance (allowing you to not actually be there for a good proportion of the year, so you can regain your sanity)
cons:
- Decisions made on basis of whoever shouts the loudest
- Short-term knee jerk actions favoured over long-term strategic planning
- Academic employees' superiority complex
- Hostile inter-departmental relations (demands issued instead of discussion, debate)
- Poor working environment (offices)
- Inability to do the basics well (employee systems, policies, processes)
- Lack of robust performance management/reward policies
- All non academic roles viewed as "administrative services" - not experts/specialist
- Lack of commercial awareness among employees
- Siloed

pros: Flexible working hours. Friendly environment. Busy working environment. The managers have been very engaging and understanding. Talented marketing staff with broad experiences
cons: Not recognising and rewarding staff for their work. Sometimes you feel hard working and efficient employees are getting treated the same way as lazy ones. It's unfair and damaging staff's motivation in long term. No career progression

review_title: An awful experience from day one
pros:
Annual leave
Pension
Work with *some* very dedicated and knowledgeable staff
cons:
Awful leadership - shambolic, self-serving and do not care about the staff
Bad location and the offices were poorly fitted out - often having to make drinks in a kitchen that stank of sewerage and had no lights. Aside from the fact they didn't supply anything anyway.  
Academic staff have no respect for anyone else in the university - management tolerate academics treating staff terribly
No career progression
Heavy workload due to terrible leadership and resourcing

review_title: Worked at Middlesex for many years
pros: The staff make excellent colleagues, most are friendly and approachable and do what they can to make a difference for students. Good salary and generous leave including maternity&paternity leave, flexible working, nice offices and buildings and open parklands nearby.
cons: Staff space is limited, but not a dealbreaker
